entry.summary:
Machines of loving grace The rituals of my tribe Legibility and communicative standards Make yourselves illegible Incoming References
Lou Keep, The Use and Abuse of Witchdoctors for Life: In 2012, the recipe for gri-gri was revealed to an elder in a dream. If you ingest it and follow certain ritual commandments, then bullets cannot harm you. The belief is puzzling, inasmuch as bullets did seem to keep killing people. More puzzling: not only did it survive, it was adopted by many neighboring villages, cities, and regions. “Why?” The paper argues that gri-gri encourages resistance on a mass scale. Beforehand, given a mix of brave and cowardly, only a small percentage of a village would fight back. If you want to have any hope of surviving, then you need everyone to fight back. Gri-gri lower…

Iterated and evolutionary game theory
entry.summary:
Background: Game theory Iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma: Basics and Strategy Population Structure and Interaction Model Competition and Evolution of Strategies Implications Population-Level Behaviors: Dependence on Initial Conditions: Unintuitive Dynamics: Incoming References
Note: The originator of the field (R. M. Axelrod 1984) is very approachable and does not require esoteric mathematical sophistication. It is a good book which you should read. The notebook is a meagre summary for the busy. The internet is full of many lavish introductions to iterated game theory, and I recommend you try some of them out. Game Theory 101, for example, has many animations and a pedagogic structure. Here we introduce an abstract model for how cooperation might evolve, or not, amongst a population of animals…

Recurrent / convolutional / state-space
entry.summary:
State space models Linear systems
Linear Time-Invariant systems
Koopman operators RNNs Transformers Stability of learning Stability of dynamics Conversion between representations S4 Incoming References
A meeting point for some related ideas from different fields. Perspectives on analysing systems in terms of a latent, noisy state, and/or their history of noisy observations. This notebook is dedicated to the possibly-surprising fact we can move between hidden-state-type representations, and observed-state-only representations, and indeed mix them together conveniently. I have many thoughts about this, but nothing concrete to write down at the moment. State space models Linear systems See linear feedback systems and linear filter design. for stuff about FIR vs IIR filters. Linear Time-Inv…

author.name: The Dan MacKinlay family of variably-well-considered enterprises

entry.title: Fastest autograd in the West
Recursive identification
entry.summary:
Classic systems learning The pushforward trick Backpropagation through time Method of adjoints References A grab-bag of perspectives and tricks for recursive identification of dynamical systems, i.e. updating a model which produces the correct forward predictions, given the past. I do a lot of work with this kind of problem, and have many thoughts about it, in particular, the complexities of recursive system identification with hidden states, and a great project would be to map out the space, even connecting it to causality. That may or may not eventually happen.
Keywords: multi-step prediction, time horizon, teacher forcing. The various things that are meant by “autoregressive”. A common core of ideas pop up here in forecasting and state filtering system identification (including particl…

Economic inequality
entry.summary:
Equality as moral good Inequality and conflict Billionaires Costs of Incoming References
Piketty, Hayek, Marx, Pareto. The supercritical Matthew effect. Informational feedback Matthew effect. This is more about political economy at scale. For models of how bias and discrimination arise in social interactions, see models of inequity. WTF is growth, and who does it? Do we care if only the minority does it? Is it a problem if technocapitalist god kings rule over a blasted landscape of diseased stunted serfs, or is that totally cool? If fine, is it sustainable? If not sustainable, does that really matter, or should we just go out with a billionaire yacht orgy on the swollen rotten oceans then blow the lights out with nukes? Equality as moral good I do not personally regard equality of outcome…

author.name: The Dan MacKinlay family of variably-well-considered enterprises

entry.title: The View Transitions API And Delightful UI Animations (Part 2)
entry.summary: The View Transitions API is a new — but game-changing — feature that allows us to do the types of reactive state-based UI and page transitions that have traditionally been exclusive to JavaScript frameworks. In the second half of this mini two-part series, Adrian Bece expands on the demos from the first article to demonstrate how the View Transitions API can be used to transition not just elements between two states but the transition between full views and pages in single-page and multi-page applications.

entry.title: Travel hacks for technomads
entry.summary:
Legal Online collaboration To bring Phone/data Comfortable flights Advanced airbnb Incoming
Legal Resources for Digital Nomads and Remote Workers (2022) Online collaboration See online collaboration. To bring See travel checklist. Phone/data datago sells 3 SIMs to Australians, which have competitive roaming rate to Europe. Top Prepaid SIM Cards for Travel is similar. Both these options are more expensive than buying local ones, but circumvent various tedious qualities of the local ones, such as onerous registration procedures and an hour of your life spent finding a vendor at an inconvenient moment. Comfortable flights TBD. Advanced airbnb Compairbnb Airplus - advanced options for Airbnb™ Roamer - Airbnb Internet Speeds / Roamer | Airbnb Internet Speeds. Not easy to discover from the download page how much it costs but may be worth it. Incoming George, Remote Roving And Digital Drudgery, Part 1 George, Remote Roving And Digital Drudgery, Part 2

Internet search engines
entry.summary:
Search with notionally good privacy
Mojeek Startpage DuckDuckGo Brave Qwant Runnaroo Search encrypt
DIY search proxies
searx mysearch
Fancy search
You Others
Decentralised search Suppressing spam Incoming Discovering my website’s search
Search with notionally good privacy I don’t want large search businesses to know what I am searching for. Also, some argue, monopoly search engines make the internet boring. Here are some links to search engines which may redress these problem. Many of these make strong claims to protect user privacy, although few offer substantive guarantees in excess of inspecting tracking headers. Some of them repackage other searches; some run their own indices. Most of them have very unclear business models. Mojeek Mojeek/Mojeek Focus (Bookmark) Search Engine Mo…

Internet for the marginally online
entry.summary:
Tools Downloading big files if you must
CLI Downthemall
macOS with bad internet
Flaky finder
You don’t live in San Francisco? Do you live somewhere with corrupt infrastructure politics, (e.g Australia,) and hence awful internet. Don’t worry, these and other deficiencies of the differently bandwidthed can be managed to be less debilitating. 🏗 Tools mosh (“mobile shell”) is a remote shell for intermittent connections. the network stack of Wechat is reputed to be robust to network shenanigans: mars, . Prefer file-sync over uploading Downloading big files if you must CLI This was my repeated-timeout download command: function wget_non_california () { until wget -c --timeout=10 $*; do sleep 10; done } ChatGPT recommends the followng wget options to robustly download: wget --load-cookies=/path/to/cookies.txt --continue --timeout=30 --tries=0 http://example.com/file That --load-cookies bit assumes that we want to download things using a browser session. For that we would need a browser extions cookies.txt Downthemall DownThemAll! has a more robust download system, and supports Firefox, Chrome and Edge macOS with bad internet Switching wifi off and on again helps. (detailed version.) Turn wifi on or off from the macOS terminal command line: networksetup -setairportpower en0 off networksetup -setairportpower en0 on Flaky finder I don’t know why this happens, but this is one of the many nasty side-effects of unreliable network connections is Finder flaking out. If your nasty ISP drops enough packets there are a whole bunch of ways that your Mac computer will DOS itself into the ground, because low bandwidth is a state alien to Apple engineers. Here are some potential workarounds: Look for misbehaving processes and corrupt wassamajiggies. Or tell Finder to stop obsessing about fancy network drives that won’t work anyway: sudo vi /etc/auto_master In this file comment out /net. Now, sudo automount -vc

kieranhealy’s walk-through, Unhappy in its Own Way is full of useful tips.
Snorkel is a hybrid method that, AFAICT, iteratively refines weak-labels (?): Today’s state-of-the-art machine learning models require massive labeled training sets — which usually do not exist for real-world applications. Instead, Snorkel is based around the new data programming paradigm, in which the developer focuses on writing a set of labeling functions, which are just scripts that programmatically label data. The resulting labels are noisy, but Snorkel automatic…

Stochastic Taylor expansion
entry.summary:
Incoming References Placeholder, for discussing the Taylor expansion equivalent for an SDE.
Let \(f\) denote a smooth function. Then, using Itô’s lemma, we may construct a local approximation by \[ f\left(X_{t}\right)=f\left(X_{0}\right)+\int_{s=0}^{t} L^{0} f\left(X_{s}\right) d s+\int_{s=0}^{t} L^{1} f\left(X_{s}\right) d B_{s} \] where the operators \(L^{0}\) and \(L^{1}\) are defined by \[ L^{0}=a(x) \frac{\partial}{\partial x}+\frac{1}{2} b(x)^{2} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}} \quad \text { and } \quad L^{1}=b(x) \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \] We may notionally repeat this procedure arbitrarily many times to take into account higher-order derivatives of the function \(f\). Each repetition produces a higher order of Itô-Taylor expansion. In practice this seems to get ugly really…

Wind stuff TBD Nuclear fission How expensive is it? How safe? It’s complicated (Wheatley, Sovacool, and Sornette 2017; Wheatley, Sovacool, and Sornette 2016) but in short, sometimes dangerous. entry.title: Narrative
entry.summary:
Incoming References
How and why narrative affects us. Leveraged in, for example, gamification and in empathy. To read: papers on whether narrative can improve empathy (Johnson, Huffman, and Jasper 2014; Bormann and Greitemeyer 2015; Oatley 2016; Kidd and Castano 2013). Incoming Michele Weldon, Your Brain on Story. Paul Zak, How Stories Change the Brain. Carol Clark, A novel look at how stories may change the brain. Malka Older’s concept of Narrative disorder. Jon Stokes, The Feed & The Tokenization of Reality is a nice hypothesis. Byrne Hobart summarizes: This is a very interesting refinement of the filter bubble thesis—it’s not just what you read, but the order in which you encounter things.… Since there are plenty of things that are more interesting when they’re taken out of context, th…

[…] he question we are interested in is: Assuming that \(m^*\) can be expressed in closed form, when is it possible to identify it as the true generating model among all possible closed-form mathematical models, for someone who does not know the true model beforehand? Extraversion
entry.summary: References A term coined by Jung (Jung 1923). Depue and Fu (2013) mentions its durability as a psychometric concept into the modern era: Extraversion represents a higher-order personality trait that has been identified in virtually all classificatory systems of the structure of personality, including Eysenck and Gray's models (Gray 1994), the Five-Factor model (Costa Jr. and McCrae 2000), Tellegen's Multidimensional Personality Questionnaire (MPQ) model (Tellegen and Waller 2008), and Zuckerman's Alternative Five-Factor model (Zuckerman 2002). The phenomenology of extraversion is described similarly in all of these models, and is characterized by adjectives that connote a state of positive affect and strong motivation of desire and wanting, as well as by feelings of being excited, enthusia…

entry.title: Worker- and founder-owned ventures
entry.summary:
Dynamic equity split models
As “slicing pie” For simple debt, this is easy
Background Sharing economy, application to Incoming References
How to trade off ownership, salary, sweat-equity, and cash investment optimally (or fairly) in new ventures. Dynamic equity split models I naively imagined that when founding a firm, a common model might be that your share of the ownership of the total equity was proportional to the value of your contribution; It took me some googling to discover that this concept is called “dynamic equity split” and in fact is considered a radical new ideal. The radical innovations are, AFAICT, the evaluating how much money and time was actually invested by all the parties when dividing up the thing. I am utterly baffled that this should be considered in any way inno…

entry.summary: After turning up hundreds of genes with hard-to-predict effects, some scientists are now probing the grander developmental processes that shape face geometry

entry.title: The remaining frontiers in fighting hepatitis C
entry.summary: A scientist whose work was key to identifying, studying and finding treatments for this life-threatening virus discusses the scientific journey and challenges that persist

entry.title: The quest to understand tornadoes
entry.summary: Scientists are still grappling with how and why violent twisters form. Will new technology and computing power help?

entry.title: Leaning into Indigenous knowledge on climate change
entry.summary: Native peoples attuned to the natural world have long collected detailed environmental information. Now scientists are cataloging these observations and learning how they’re affecting Indigenous communities globally.

entry.title: Pursuing fusion power
entry.summary: Scientists have been chasing the dream of harnessing the reactions that power the Sun since the dawn of the atomic era. Interest, and investment, in the carbon-free energy source is heating up.

entry.title: How wind turbines could coexist peacefully with bats and birds
entry.summary: As wind power grows around the world, so does the threat the turbines pose to wildlife. From simple fixes to high-tech solutions, new approaches can help.

entry.title: Does it work to pay people not to cut the forest?
entry.summary: Evidence that the approach helps to save trees, preserve ecosystems and reduce carbon emissions is often hard to come by. But it can succeed if it’s done right, says an economist.

entry.title: New devices could change the way we measure blood pressure
entry.summary: Embedded in a cell phone or in accessories such as rings, bracelets or watches, the novel tools aim to make it easier to manage hypertension. But they must still pass several tests before hitting the clinic.

entry.title: Where the heck did all those structures inside complex cells come from?
entry.summary: Scientists agree that eons ago, a bacterium took up residence inside another cell and became its powerhouse, the mitochondrion. But there are competing theories about the birth of other organelles such as the nucleus and endoplasmic reticulum.

entry.title: Division of labor in ants, wasps, bees — and us
entry.summary: Social insects and humans share the trait of divvying up tasks, as do some fish. Researchers find that it emerges naturally, and it often doesn’t take a boss to keep things in order.

entry.title: Everyone should start counting spiders
entry.summary: Our collective arachnid aversion could be causing us to overlook something even scarier: Spiders may be disappearing.

entry.title: As the climate changes, plants must shift their ranges. But can they?
entry.summary: Lots of them depend on fruit-eating birds and mammals to spread their seeds. But it’s debatable whether the animals — many in trouble themselves — can disperse seeds far and fast enough to keep pace with a warming world.

entry.title: The race to understand polar ice sheets
entry.summary: As glacial cliffs break off and destabilize frozen landscapes, glaciologist Richard Alley focuses on the fractures. The work could improve predictions about future sea-level rise.

entry.title: Neanderthals: More knowable now than ever
entry.summary: They have held our fascination ever since we first identified their remains. Today, thanks to new artifacts and technologies, findings about our closest relatives are coming thick and fast.

entry.title: Why scientists are making transparent wood
entry.summary: Stronger than plastic and tougher than glass, the resin-filled material is being exploited for smartphone screens, insulated windows and more

entry.title: In the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, new marine ecosystems are flourishing

entry.title: Green shipping picks up speed

Comment systems for static websites
entry.summary:
Bake comments into the site code Hypothes.is Self-hosted comment server Hosted comment server less suspect than disqus Comments as github issues Comments as github discussions
commenters in the shade of a blog post Hosting comments is a weak point for static sites, since by definition there is no content server to wait around for random drive-by interactions from the internet. But it is feasible by leveraging various other hosted services, in a slightly laborious, quirky, two-tiers-of-content kind of way. I used the hosted Disqus system but it was bloated and suspect, so I seek alternatives. Start with Cloudcannon’s Commenting for Jamstack overview Ben Fedidat’s reviews. Hugo’s suggestions Peter Baumgartner’s reviews There is a virtue in staying with well supported options— e.g. quarto su…

CRDT Concepts: Causal Trees
Superstimuli
entry.summary:
Fun recent occurrences of the idea Incoming References
Somewhere around the Goodhart-Moloch-supernormal-alignment-utility-addiction area, we find the concept of superstimuli, things that feel better for us than they actually are for us. Fun recent occurrences of the idea Erik Hoel, Exit the supersensorium touches upon many themes; dreaming, addiction, myths and the entertainment-industrial complex. See also Living in the Supersensorium - by David Gasca. Musical Heresies by Roger’s Bacon makes the case for music being an evolved superstimulus. The is a connection to adversarial training, in that while superstimuli might not be created with intent and foreknowledge to blow someone's mind, (they might though), they are often evolved in some kind of competitive process, such as evolution or market competition, or algorithmic optimization.
Incoming Naomi Klein was not the first but maybe the most famous exponent of the idea of branding-as-superstimulus (Klein 2010) Time Flies: U.S. Adults Now Spend Nearly Half a Day Interacting with Media References “Models That Learn How Humans Learn: The Case of Decision-Making and Its Disorders.” PLOS Computational Biology 15 (6): e1006903.
Dezfouli, Amir, Richard Nock, and Peter Dayan. 2020. “Adversarial Vulnerabilities of Human Decision-Making.” Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 117 (46): 29221–28.
Klein, Naomi. 2010. No Logo. 10th Anniversary edition. 4th Estate GB.
Kozyreva, Anastasia, Sam Wineburg, Stephan Lewandowsky, and Ralph Hertwig. 2023. “Critical Ignoring as a Core Competence for Digital Citizens.” Current Directions in Psychological Science 32 (1): 81–88.
Paasonen, Susanna. 2021. Dependent, Distracted, Bored: Affective Formations in Networked Media.

Software audio routers
entry.summary:
By platform
macOS Linux Windows
Jack ios Audio routers are patching writ large.
Audio routers are “virtual cables” that route audio out of limited parochial software into differently limited parochial software, giving us flexibility in our audio process at the cost of confusion and labour. Using audio effects software to apply effects to audio synthesis software doesn’t sound like it is that weird an idea, but turns out to be tedious. There are many software solutions that I am aware of, with different reliability, licensing, and platform support. 2023 update: Streamlined solutions for twitch and gam streamers have leveled up the ease here, often free. RØDE’s UNIFY — Virtual Mixing Software for Streaming and Content Creation is free and seems easy, designed to route output from some app…

entry.title: ChatGPT plugins
entry.summary: We’ve implemented initial support for plugins in ChatGPT. Plugins are tools designed specifically for language models with safety as a core principle, and help ChatGPT access up-to-date information, run computations, or use third-party services.

entry.title: GPTs are GPTs: An early look at the labor market impact potential of large language models
GPT-4
entry.summary: We’ve created GPT-4, the latest milestone in OpenAI’s effort in scaling up deep learning. GPT-4 is a large multimodal model (accepting image and text inputs, emitting text outputs) that, while less capable than humans in many real-world scenarios, exhibits human-level performance on various professional and academic benchmarks.
